pages:
Technical Assistance Report 
 
 
 
 
   
 
 
 
 
 
 
Project Number: 45261-001 
Regional–Policy  and Advisory Technical Assistance (R-PATA) 
December 2011 
 
 
 
 
Improving Agricultural and Rural Statistics  
for Food Security

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  ESCAP  –  United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and 
the Pacific 
  FAO  –  Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations 
  SGAS  –  steering group for agricultural statistics 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type   –  Regional–Policy and advisory technical assistance (R-PATA) 
 
Targeting classification   –  General intervention (indirectly addressing poverty reduction) 
 
Sectors (subsectors)  –  Agriculture and natural resources (agriculture and rural sector 
development), public sector management (economic and public 
affairs management)  
 
Themes (subthemes)  –  Governance (public administration [national, decentralized, and 
regional]); capacity development (institutional development); social 
development (human development); economic growth (promoting 
macroeconomic stability) 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, ―$‖ refers to US dollars. 
 
 
Vice-President  B. N. Lohani, Knowledge Management and Sustainable Development 
Group 
Chief Economist  C. Rhee, Economics and Research Department (ERD) 
Assistant Chief Economist  D. Brooks, Development Indicators and Policy Research Division, ERD 
   
Team leader  D. S. Maligalig, Principal Statistician, ERD 
Team members  E. Go, Economics and Statistics Officer, ERD 
  M. Katagami, Natural Resources and Agriculture Specialist, Agriculture, 
Rural Development and Food Security Unit, Regional and Sustainable 
Development Department 
P. Lapitan, Associate Statistics and Economics Analyst, ERD 
  G. Sugiyarto, Senior Economist, ERD  
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

1 
I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  At the invitation of the United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the 
Pacific (ESCAP),1 the Asian Development Bank (ADB) agreed to collaborate with ESCAP in 
developing and implementing a regional action plan for implementing the Global Strategy for 
Improving Agricultural and Rural Statistics for enhanced food security in the Asia and Pacific 
region. The global strategy, which was endorsed by the United Nations Statistical Commission 
in  February 2010,  provides  a  framework  within  which  national  and  international  statistical 
systems can produce and apply basic data and information to guide decision making in the 
21st century. The strategy rests on three pillars: (i) the establishment of a minimum set of core 
data that countries will collect to meet current and emerging demands, (ii) the integration of 
agriculture into national statistical systems to satisfy the demands of policy makers and other 
users  who  rely  on  comparable  data  across  locations  and  time,  and  (iii) the  institution  of 
sustainable agricultural statistics systems through governance and statistical capacity building.  
 
2.  ADB formulated this technical assistance (TA) to support this process. (The design and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.)2  In the planning of this TA, partner agencies—the Food 
and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) and ESCAP—and several people 
representing the national statistical systems of the Philippines and Bhutan were consulted. In 
addition, ADB, other development organizations, and countries in the region will be represented 
in a steering group for agricultural statistics that was formed to spearhead the development of 
the regional implementation plan. 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  A majority of the poor in the region still live in the rural areas, and agriculture is still the 
major source of employment. To achieve inclusive growth, therefore, agriculture and the rural 
areas must develop and the effects on future food security of population growth, demand for 
natural resources and competing food crop use, and extreme weather and climate change must 
be understood. For these issues to be examined and appropriate policies to be formulated, 
there must be accurate, reliable, and comprehensive data on agriculture and the rural areas. 
Many developing countries in Asia and the Pacific do not have the necessary data support 
systems. 
  
4.  Many  of  the  crop  production  data  and  other  agricultural  statistics  that  developing 
member countries (DMCs) use come from those countries’ administrative reporting systems. 
Government  agricultural  personnel  assess  crop  production  by  observing  harvests  and  by 
interviewing  experts  (village  heads, farmers,  traders)  in  their  assigned  localities.  Summary 
statistics from lower levels of government are then transmitted up the hierarchy until they reach 
the national level. While this data collection approach is inexpensive and can provide timely 
data, research has shown that it is prone to large measurement errors. Data collection officers 
and others involved in the process have vested interests that influence the estimation process. 
Agricultural officers tend to overestimate production in their assigned areas to support their 
claims of accomplishment. This type of administrative reporting does not usually include a 
validation process that could improve the quality of estimates.  
                                                
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
1 The invitation dated 24 May 2011 came from ESCAP’s executive secretary and the chair of the committee on 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.  
statistics, a subsidiary body of ESCAP composed of heads of national statistical systems of ESCAP member 
 
countries dedicated to the development of official statistics in Asia and the Pacific. In accepting the invitation on 
  27 June 2011, the ADB President emphasized the need to improve agriculture to achieve inclusive growth. 
2   The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of the ADB website on 17 October 2011.

2   
 
5.  Inaccurate estimation of staple food production can lead to inappropriate policies and, 
consequently,  unfavorable  outcomes,  and  possibly  worsening  food  security.  Because  only 
aggregated statistics are available, analysis at the household level is not feasible. Households 
that are food insecure cannot be accurately profiled and vulnerable areas identified. In general, 
data-intensive analysis that can inform policy and contribute to better development outcomes in 
the long term is not forthcoming.  
 
6.  While administrative reporting systems can improve by incorporating a data validation 
process, the preferred data collection strategy makes use of a system of household surveys, in 
which agricultural data, such as crop and backyard livestock production, farming operations, 
landholdings, and other related data items, are collected directly from sample households that 
were objectively selected. This approach provides sound estimates, the ability to estimate 
sampling errors to gauge the quality of estimates, and, more importantly, household-level data 
for more data-intensive analysis. However, only 16 of the 45 DMCs in the region have regular, 
nationally representative surveys for collecting agricultural statistics, and only 20 conduct an 
agriculture census every 10 years that can be used as sampling frame for surveys, to enrich 
policy analysis and support government planning.  
7.  The  global  strategy  recommends  the  implementation  of  a  master  sample3  as  the 
preferred method of generating agricultural and rural data of better coverage and quality. At 
present only three DMCs maintain a master sample for their household survey system, which 
does not include agricultural and rural surveys. In fact, 14 of the 45 DMCs do not conduct any 
household surveys at all, and 13 have irregular data collection systems that depend mostly on 
the availability of external funding. In the 18 countries that have regular household surveys, crop 
production and other related statistics are usually compiled by the agriculture ministry rather 
than by the national statistics office as part of household surveys of national coverage.  
 
8.  For poverty assessment and reduction household surveys must be designed to provide 
reliable estimates for the urban and rural areas. While some countries with regular household 
survey systems derive estimates disaggregated into urban and rural components, many other 
countries turn out official statistics without this level of disaggregation. 
     
9.  Even  with  many  desired  features,  such  as  the  enrichment  of  data-intensive  policy 
research and better-quality estimates, probability sample surveys may not be a straightforward 
replacement for administrative reporting for national statistical systems. Surveys are much more 
costly, and because survey data go through rigorous data validation, estimates and the survey 
report may not be available as quickly. Moreover, agricultural and rural statistics are often not 
considered core statistics and for that reason, are not given a regular budgetary allocation. 
External financing of surveys and censuses is not sustainable in the long run, however, and will 
only  make  countries  dependent  on  external  funding.  The  government  must  therefore  be 
committed to producing agricultural and rural statistics at the outset. Developing countries 
should  give  priority  to  drafting  affordable  data  collection  strategies  and  taking  innovative 
approaches to the use of remote sensing and other satellite-related technologies. 
 
10.  The sustainability of agricultural and rural statistics hinges on governments’ support, 
which in turn is contingent on demand for these statistics. This demand is assumed to be high in 
the global strategy paper, but it is not adequately met in many countries in Asia and the Pacific 
because of the poor quality and coverage of agricultural and rural statistics. Higher-quality 
                                                
3  A sample from which subsamples can be selected to serve the needs of more than one survey or survey round. It 
is a set of sample units from which further selection may be done.

3 
agricultural  and  rural  statistics  can  be  invaluable  to  policy  makers  in  monitoring  their 
governments’ development plans. Therefore, agricultural and rural statistics  must be integrated 
not  only  into  the  countries’  statistical  development  plans  but  also  into  their  economic 
development plans. 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The intended impact of the proposed TA is an increase in the use of agricultural and 
rural statistics in policy making to enhance food security. The expected outcome is an increase 
in agricultural and rural statistics of better quality that are collected regularly. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The TA will consist of three major activities: (i) regional action plan  preparation, to 
improve agriculture and rural statistics; (ii) methodological studies; and (iii) training programs 
and workshops, to support countries in developing their own action plans.  
 
13.  To develop the regional action plan, ESCAP and FAO have organized a steering group 
for agricultural statistics (SGAS) in which countries in the region4 as well as ADB and other 
development organizations5 are represented. The SGAS is envisioned to provide a venue for 
broader consultation on the development of the regional action plan and for the promotion of the 
endeavor among countries and the development community in the region.  
 
14.  To ensure that the action plan comes with an appropriate set of development tools for 
countries that have expressed interest in improving their agricultural and rural statistics, an 
assessment of countries in the region will be made on the basis of available information that has 
already been collected by development organizations. The following criteria will be used in the 
assessment:  (i)  level  of  food  security,  (ii)  capability  to  conduct  household  surveys,  and 
(iii) government support for agricultural and rural statistics.  
 
15.  Countries with well-functioning household survey systems that include agricultural and 
rural statistics will be encouraged to help other countries by sharing information about their 
statistical methods. ADB will also work as a catalyst, soliciting the advice and participation of 
these countries and providing a suitable collaboration mechanism for the development of the 
action plans. Administrative reporting systems and other approaches will have to be studied and 
developed for countries without any household survey system at all. Surveys in these countries 
may not be affordable and are likely to be difficult to process and analyze given the human 
resource and infrastructure constraints of the national statistics offices.  
 
16.    Methodological research through special studies and surveys will be carried out to 
develop affordable data collection strategies for agricultural and rural statistics. For example, 
instead of a new survey of farming and livestock activities, a module dealing with this topic can 
be introduced into the household income and expenditure survey, which is one of the two 
                                                
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
4m  Aefmghbaenriss,t aBno, aAruds toraf lDiai,r eBcatnogrlsa,d Mesahn, aBgheumtane n(vt,i coer- cshtaaifrf),,  aInnddia m, Ianyd obnee spirae, lIirmanin, aJrayp ainn ,n tahteu rMea. l dives, Myanmar, the 
Philippines (chair), Sri Lanka, Thailand, and Viet Nam. 
 
5 The Asia and Pacific Commission on Agricultural Statistics, ESCAP, FAO, the Indian Agricultural Statistics 
 
Research  Institute,  the  International  Fund  for  Agricultural  Development,  the  Department  for  International 
  Development of the United Kingdom, and the Secretariat  for the Pacific Community.

4   
surveys that are most regularly conducted.6 The sampling strategies used in household survey 
systems must be examined and, if necessary, revised to ensure that the sample sizes for the 
rural areas are adequate. ADB will also work with key government agencies on joint policy 
analyses using available data from existing household surveys. This approach could widen the 
user  base  for  agricultural  and  rural  statistics  and  thereby  increase  the  demand  for  these 
statistics and secure the necessary budget appropriation from the government for this purpose.  
 
17.  Since food security needs to be measured more frequently, food security questions can 
be included in the survey that is most often conducted—the labor force survey. This approach is 
expected to be more cost effective than enjoining countries to conduct a new full survey round. 
Special studies will be done to streamline the household income and expenditure survey and 
the labor force survey with these additional modules and not increase the response burden. 
Consultations  will  also  help  determine  data  ownership  and  reporting  responsibilities—for 
example, should the national statistics office or the ministry of agriculture compile and own the 
data?   
 
18.  Workshops will be held to assist in the development of the regional action plan and the 
country plans and to disseminate the results of the methodological research. Training programs 
in survey design and operations and in policy analysis will support the development of country 
plans and upgrade the skills of national statistical systems staff. Participation in the training 
programs will be based on the results of the country assessment. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
19.  The cost of the TA is estimated at $500,000. ADB will finance the country assessment 
and will support, where necessary (considering the results of the assessment), the development 
of the regional action plan, the conduct of methodological research, the cost of the international 
and national consulting services, and the conduct of workshops and training programs. The TA 
will be financed with a grant from ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF—other 
sources). The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
20.  ADB will be the executing agency for this TA. It will collaborate closely with ESCAP, 
FAO, and SGAS members throughout the project to minimize duplication of efforts and leverage 
the  limited  available  resources.  The  TA  will  be  implemented  over  18  months,  from 
December 2011 to June 2013.  
 
21.  Memorandums of agreement will be drawn up with the national statistical offices that will 
conduct the methodological research. These agreements will specify the appropriate financial 
management  facility,  including  the  nature  of  the  advance  payment  facility.  International 
development organizations that are active in agricultural research may be consulted as required 
during the methodological research. National statistical offices will be encouraged to collaborate 
with national research and academic institutions in the methodological research. 
 
22.  The  TA  will  also  finance  2  person-months  (intermittent)  of  international  and 
12 person-months  of  national  consulting  services.  ADB  will  hire  individual  consultants  in 
accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). 
The terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3. 
                                                
6  The labor force survey is the household survey that is most frequently conducted.

5 
 
23.  Disbursements  under  the  TA  will  be  made  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). The procurement of 
equipment, if any, will follow ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to 
time).  
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
24.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis for 
Improving Agricultural and Rural Statistics for Food Security, and hereby reports this action to 
the Board. 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

Appendix 3  9 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
 
A.  Agricultural Statistician (international consultant, 2 person-months, intermittent) 
1.  The  agricultural  statistician  should  have  a  strong  background  in  the  methods  of 
compiling agricultural and rural statistics and in the design of sample surveys, especially in 
developing countries with limited funds for data collection.  
 
2.  The consultant will perform the following specific tasks: 
(i)  undertake the initial country assessment on the basis of available data and 
information  from  the  websites  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank,  the  United 
Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific, the Food and 
Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, and the World Bank; 
(ii)  recommend a workable country group classification and necessary actions to 
improve the countries’ agricultural and rural statistics; 
(iii)  work with the project officer and selected countries in planning methodological 
research, advise the countries, and review reports; 
(iv)  assist in drafting the implementation plan for Asia; and 
(v)  assist the countries in developing their own implementation plans. 
 
 
B.  Statistician (national consultant, 12 person-months) 
1.  The statistician should have an extensive background in statistical methods, the analysis 
of household surveys, and statistical software programming.  
 
2.  The consultant will perform the following specific tasks: 
(i)  assist in the initial country assessment by providing analytical support to the 
agricultural statistician and the project officer; 
(ii)  help in organizing seminars, training, and conferences; 
(iii)  provide technical support to the project officer in coordinating with the various 
countries; and 
(iv)  assist in methodological research and in report preparation.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  ESCAP  –  United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and 
the Pacific 
  FAO  –  Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations 
  SGAS  –  steering group for agricultural statistics 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type   –  Regional–Policy and advisory technical assistance (R-PATA) 
 
Targeting classification   –  General intervention (indirectly addressing poverty reduction) 
 
Sectors (subsectors)  –  Agriculture and natural resources (agriculture and rural sector 
development), public sector management (economic and public 
affairs management)  
 
Themes (subthemes)  –  Governance (public administration [national, decentralized, and 
regional]); capacity development (institutional development); social 
development (human development); economic growth (promoting 
macroeconomic stability) 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, ―$‖ refers to US dollars.
